body:
Hi @aiwalter and @koralturkk - this sounds like an interesting idea! I'm a little hesitant on adding TensorFlow Probability as a soft dependency because we had several issues with integrating it into the CI/CD workflows in other projects (sktime-dl especially). A may be a better idea to work on this in a companion repository. 

If this is something you're interested in, I'm happy to create one under the sktime organisation and give you admin rights. Since this would be a pure Python package, setting up CI/CD pipelines to check compatibility with the main repo shouldn't be too difficult either. 

Regarding the design: Could you show me what you have in mind for the user journey? How would models be encapsulated in a forecaster class?

@mloning thx for feedback. Regarding design, `BSTS` works with components, so the user is free to add several of them to a model. In the following example, there are two components, `sts.LocalLinearTrend` and `sts.Seasonal`:
```python
def build_model(observed_time_series):
  trend = sts.LocalLinearTrend(observed_time_series=observed_time_series)
  seasonal = sts.Seasonal(
      num_seasons=12, observed_time_series=observed_time_series)
  model = sts.Sum([trend, seasonal], observed_time_series=observed_time_series)
  return model
```
So in `sts.Sum` the components are build together to one model. How to provide the user this flexibility comes back to the question above where I wrote down the 2 options I had in mind of how to deal with component. Basically this components will be given to `sktime.BSTS()` as arguments. The function `build_model` from the exmaple could be a part of the `_instantiate_model()` function.
Regarding adding this to `sktime`, I would propose we give it a try to get it running with CI. Now I have also @koralturkk to get it running on all platforms.

Hm, regarding design:
I think aiming for *both* wrapped individual components and wrapped composites makes sense here! If I had to choose, I'd say to aim for wrapped composites, since that is more flexible and robust with regards to extensions and changes of `BSTS`.

The "really nice thing", design-wise, would be adding a compiler-like layer that recognizes when adjacent sktime components are from `BSTS` and replaces them by a wrapped (and more efficient) `BSTS` composite. But perhaps out of scope due to complexity...

Regarding dependencies: as @mloning says, one of these days, we need to fix how we manage the neural network package dependencies. Currently, we have no maintainer dedicated to that family of dependencies - it is quite some work to keep these spinning, so help would be very much welcome.
The problem is greater than just `BSTS`, it is essentially "anything that depends on tf", so it would be maintaining "time series models using deep learning packages".

Ok, we can give it a try to integrate it into sktime! 

But we may have to make a difficult decision to not include it in the end, if we need to touch too much of the CI/CD pipeline, and move it to a separate repo. I worry about the extra maintenance burden for the CI/CD pipelines when upgrading versions later on. We have had similar issues with other packages already (e.g. the ongoing work to integrate the signature-based module).

issue.title: Feature extension bsts

labels.name: interfacing algorithms
labels.description: Interfacing existing algorithms/estimators for other packages

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
Implementing Algorithm #612

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Wrapper for tensorflow-probability to add BSTS model.


#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?
`tensorflow-probability
`
#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?
<!-- This section is particularly useful if you have a pull request that is still in development. You can guide the reviews to focus on the parts that are ready for their comments. We suggest using bullets (indicated by * or -) and filled checkboxes [x] here -->

##### For all contributions
- [x] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/.all-contributorsrc).
- [x] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [x] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.

##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [x] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->

body: Closing as we have now `UnobservedComponents` which seems to be similar
is it? I'd consider it a different estimator.
my work mate looked into it and said, that `UnobservedComponents` is basically BSTS without the B (Bayesian) part.

Yes, I have no problems removing "Bayesian" from anything, but just on the conceptual level it's a different algorithm and estimator - as you just confirm (because "without the B part" implies that it's different!)

So I think it's still a reasonable aspiration to have the Bayesian variant interfaced, and strictly speaking it's not addressed by having an interface to `UnobservedComponents`.
Ok then lets keep it open

issue.title: Forecasting wish list

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
For the API design proposal, see [this wiki entry](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/wiki/Forecasting-API-proposal).

## Forecasters
### Atomic 
- [x] NaiveForecaster (strategies={"last",  "mean", "seasonal_last"}) #227 
- [x] PolynomialTrendForecaster (linear, polynomial, locally linear, smoothing splines), see this [chapter](https://otexts.com/fpp2/nonlinear-regression.html)
- [x] [ThetaForecaster](https://github.com/M4Competition/M4methods/blob/master/4Theta%20method.R) #198 
- [x] ExponentialSmoothing #198 
- [x] ARIMA #412 
- [x] AutoARIMA #104 
- [x] Automatic Exponential Smoothing, see [ETS](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/forecast/versions/8.12/topics/ets) in R, [source code](https://github.com/robjhyndman/forecast/blob/master/R/ets.R), see https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/350, statsmodels: https://www.statsmodels.org/dev/examples/notebooks/generated/ets.html
- [x] Croston's method #730 
- [x] Theta
- [x] Prophet
- [x] UnobserverdComponents #1394  
- [ ] Bayesian structural time series models (see #612), see also https://github.com/WillianFuks/tfcausalimpact

### Reduction
- [x] ReducedRegressionForecaster, see #218 
- [x] ReducedTimeSeriesRegressionForecaster, see #218 

### Composition
- [x] TransformedTargetForecaster (pipeline with target transformations, multiple steps)
- [x] EnsembleForecaster (see e.g. sklearn's [VotingRegressor](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.ensemble.VotingRegressor.html#sklearn.ensemble.VotingRegressor))
- [x] StackingForecaster
- [x] ColumnEnsembler, multiple univariate forecasters on multivariate time series (forecasting trend and residuals separately, adding/multiplying results together) #1082 
- [x] FeatureUnion to get multiple transforms from a single time series (univariate to multivariate)
- [ ] Concatenator (or splicer) to get single series from segments of series in a pipelines with prior annotation and splicing according to annotations
- [ ] ensemble over steps in forecasting horizon ("direct strategy") which fits a separate model for each step ahead
- [x] other ensemble methods (weighted averages, etc) 
- [x] Recursive strategy (basically https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.multioutput.RegressorChain.html#sklearn.multioutput.RegressorChain)
- [x] Direct strategy (basically https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.multioutput.MultiOutputRegressor.html)
- [x] DirRec strategy #226 
- [x] support for models that inherently support multi-output (see e.g. https://machinelearningmastery.com/multi-output-regression-models-with-python/)

### Interfaces
- [x] statsmodels
- [x] pmdarima
- [x] fbprophet
- [ ] gluonts

### Multivariate/vector forecasting
- [x] TransformedTargetForecaster #1376 
- [x] NaiveForecaster #1401 
- [x] ForecastingPipeline #1376 
- [x] ForecastingGridSearchCV #1376 
- [x] RandomizedGridSearchCV #1376 
- [x] MultiplexForecaster #1376 
- [ ] make_reduction
- [ ] EnsembleForecaster
- [ ] AutoEnsembleForecaster
- [ ] StackingForecaster

## Transformers
- [x] Detrender (series to series, meta-estimator that works with any forecaster)
- [x] Deseasonaliser
- [x] FittedParamExtractor for regression/classification
- [x] BoxCoxTransformer (see [pmdarima's implementation](https://alkaline-ml.com/pmdarima/modules/generated/pmdarima.preprocessing.BoxCoxEndogTransformer.html))
- [x] Wrapper for sklearn's non-fittable transformers, so that we can apply them to single series (e.g. FunctionTransformer or scalers)
- [ ] TimeSeriesDecomposer (e.g. using LOESS seasonal-trend-residual decomposition) returning multivariate series 
- [x] OptionalPassthrough #762 
- [x] FeatureSelection #1347 
- [x] Imputer #1461 
- [x] SummaryTransformer #1329  
- [x] Differencer #945  
- [x] STL #1463 
- [x] DateTimeFeatures #1356
- [ ] Featurizer #1443 
- [x] MeanTransformer
- [x] SqrtTransformer #1127 
- [x] ThetaLines #923 
- [x] ExponentTransformer #1127 
- [ ] Smoothing transformer(s)
- [ ] Function transformer 

## Model selection
### Temporal CV
- [x] SlidingWindowSplitter
- [x] ManualWindowSplitter
- [x] SingleWindowSplitter
- [x] temporal_train_test_split
- [x] MultiplexForecaster #715 
- [x] ExpandingWindowSplitter

### Tuning
- [x] ForecastingGridSearchCV

## Pipelines
- [x] ForecastingPipeline (pipe on X)
- [ ] Advanced/unified Pipeline (see STEP https://github.com/sktime/enhancement-proposals/blob/main/steps/01_forecasting_api/forecasting_pipeline.md) 
- [ ] NetworkPipeline #856 

## Enhancements
- [x] in-sample predictions
- [x] prediction intervals (new interface)
- [ ] dynamic (using previously predicted values) vs static predictions
- [x] exogenous variables, including pipelines, multivariate transformers, etc
- [x] simplify `FH` class into separate utility functions
- [x] refactor `ForecastingGridSearchCV` and `update_predict()`, try to factor out separate cross-validation function

body: Added this to the wish list and closed the issue since we won't be implementing this via tensorflow.
